definition: Also known as "Auto." It is the first 15 seconds of the match when the robots are completely driverless, running on pre-programmed instructions. This was used prior to 2019.
It is also called Stop Build (See "Stop Build")
The website that collects FRC stats, including live tournament data (www.thebluealliance.com).
a wire that connects specific devices and communicates to them within the robot.
a "bus" for mechanical systems. They are the green and yellow wires on the robot.
a list of every component on the robot and its cost.
Also known as FIRST Championships. Where regional/district winners, chairman’s, Engineering Inspiration, and wild card recipients from all over the world compete. Hosted in Houston and Detroit.
When a team builds a robot part for an alliance partner, not their own robot. For example, building a blocker to put on a partner robot in a match.
FRC team 254 from California. One of the best teams in the world.
A forum for FIRST teams around the world to ask and answer questions.
a piece of aluminum structure used for support. Shaped like the food churro.
A motor usually used in drive trains.
Preventing the other alliance from scoring. How it's used varies from year to year.
The final field at championships.
For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology
Field Management System. It connects to all robots and runs the matches.
short for FIRST Robotics Competition; the FIRST program that we compete in
FIRST Technical Advisor. This person makes sure the field runs smoothly during matches.

part of the ethos of FIRST. It's a way of doing things that encourages high-quality work, emphasizes the value of others, and respects individuals and the community. (This definition was taken from the FIRST website)
a sensor that detects rotational movement.
A night roughly a month after school begins. KnightKrawler gives a one hour presentation about the team for new students who are interested in joining.
A person who makes sure that robots are safe and legal at competitions.
An offseason competition in November hosted by FRC Team 2169.
Minnesota Robotics Invitational. It is an offseason competition hosted by FRC Team 2846.
a type of wheel that allows the robot to move sideways.
short for "Parents of KnightKrawler"
a mini computer.
the first 15 seconds of the match. Robots can be autonomous (see "Autonomous") or camera operated. New in 2019.
watching and analyzing other teams during competitions to collect data for team selection. We use our app FRC Krawler.
the last day teams are allowed to work on their robot during the 6 week build period, after which, they must put their robot in a bag until their first competition.
planning for optimal performance in competition and alliance selection.
all four wheels can rotate right to left.
Drilling many holes in the robot to lose weight.
a motor controller.
a vendor that sells parts we use on our robot.
A practice competition the last week of build season hosted by FRC Teams 2052 and 2472.
a type of structural metal that has grooves on all four sides. Used mostly for mounting support.
